movies.title: Tokyo Story
movies.plot: An elderly couple journey to Tokyo to visit their children and are confronted by indifference, ingratitude and selfishness. When the parents are packed off to a resort by their impatient children, the film deepens into an unbearably moving meditation on mortality.
movies.simplePlot: An old couple visit their children and grandchildren in the city; but the children have little time for them.

biography.bio: What an amazing career! Few can boast a longer one (64 years of activity). Few have been able to have to relate to three generations. And it is pretty sure that no one can compare with him in terms of faithfulness to a director: Chishu Ryu indeed appeared in no fewer than fifty-two out of fifty-four of his master Yasujirô Ozu. He played in 187 films or TV films and could be a very versatile actor: for instance in 1936, when he was thirty, he embodied a student in one film and an old man in another. However he was perfect in Ozu's films, most often, as a simple, unobtrusive man whose humanity is revealed through the hardships of everyday life. How could Japanese cinema have done without Chishu Ryu?
biography.name: Chishû Ryû

biography.bio: Chieko Higashiyama was born on September 30, 1890 in Chiba, Japan as Sen Watanabe. She was an actress, known for Tokyo Story (1953), Début d'été (1951) and The Idiot (1951). She died on May 8, 1980.
biography.name: Chieko Higashiyama

biography.bio: Setsuko Hara became one of Japan's best-loved stars over her 30-year film career. Her signature character type, variations on a daughter devoted to her parents and home, inspired the nickname that stayed with her until retirement: the Eternal Virgin. To some extent, reality mirrored her roles in these films. In a society that considers marriage and parenting almost obligatory, she remained single and childless, something of a controversy in Japan in the 1950s. Fortunately she was popular enough to avoid criticism, but the 1950s were still a hard decade. She was plagued by ill health, missing out on several top roles as a result, and she witnessed the death of her camera-man brother in a freak train accident on set. In 1963, shortly after the death of her mentor, director Yasujirô Ozu, she suddenly walked away from the film industry. At age 43, and at the height of her popularity, she bluntly refused to perform again, angering her fans, the industry, and the press. She implied acting had never been a pleasure and that she had only pursued a career in order to provide for her large family; this explanation is seen as the cause of her popularity backlash. She moved to a small house in picturesque Kamakura where she remained, living alone (though apparently sociable with friends), and refusing all roles offered. She is undoubtedly known mostly for her work with Yasujiro Ozu, making six films with the great director, including the so-called Noriko trilogy, of which Tokyo Story (1953) is probably the best-known. She also worked with Akira Kurosawa, Mikio Naruse, Hiroshi Inagaki, and many others.
biography.name: Setsuko Hara

biography.bio: Haruko Sugimura was born on January 6, 1909 in Hiroshima, Japan. She was an actress, known for Tokyo Story (1953), Late Spring (1949) and Le testament du soir (1995). She died on April 4, 1997 in Tokyo, Japan.
biography.name: Haruko Sugimura

biography.bio: Sô Yamamura was born on February 24, 1910 in Tenri, Japan as Hirosada Koga. He was an actor and director, known for Tora! Tora! Tora! (1970), Tokyo Story (1953) and Gung Ho (1986). He was married to Yuriko Yamamura. He died on May 26, 2000 in Suginami, Tokyo, Japan.
biography.name: Sô Yamamura

biography.bio: Kuniko Miyake was born on September 17, 1916 in Saitama, Japan. She was an actress, known for Tokyo Story (1953), Début d'été (1951) and Late Spring (1949). She died on November 4, 1992 in Japan.
biography.name: Kuniko Miyake

biography.bio: Kyôko Kagawa was born on December 5, 1931 in Ibaraki, Japan as Kyoko Ikebe. She is an actress, known for High and Low (1963), Tokyo Story (1953) and Sansho the Bailiff (1954).
biography.name: Kyôko Kagawa

biography.bio: Eijirô Tôno was born on September 17, 1907 in Gunma, Japan. He was an actor, known for Seven Samurai (1954), Yojimbo (1961) and Tora! Tora! Tora! (1970). He died on September 8, 1994.
biography.name: Eijirô Tôno

biography.bio: Nobuo Nakamura was born on September 14, 1908 in Otaru, Hokkaido, Japan. He was an actor, known for Ikiru (1952), Tokyo Story (1953) and High and Low (1963). He died on July 5, 1991.
biography.name: Nobuo Nakamura

biography.bio: Shirô Ôsaka was born on February 14, 1920 in Noshiro, Akita, Japan. He was an actor, known for Tokyo Story (1953), Pigs and Battleships (1961) and Morning for the Osone Family (1946). He died on March 3, 1989.
biography.name: Shirô Ôsaka

biography.placeOfBirth: Koami-cho, Nihonbashi-ku, Tokyo, Japan [now Nihonbashi Koami-cho, Chuo-ku, Tokyo]
biography.bio: Hisao Toake was born on September 8, 1908 in Koami-cho, Nihonbashi-ku, Tokyo, Japan. He was an actor, known for Tokyo Story (1953), Tora! Tora! Tora! (1970) and Street of Shame (1956). He died on December 18, 1985.
biography.name: Hisao Toake

biography.bio: Teruko Nagaoka was born on January 5, 1908 in Morioka, Iwate, Japan as Teruko Shinohara. She was an actress, known for Tokyo Story (1953), Le grondement de la montagne (1954) and Good Morning (1959). She died on October 18, 2010 in Tokyo, Japan.
biography.name: Teruko Nagaoka

biography.bio: Mutsuko Sakura was born on February 15, 1921 in Tokyo, Japan. She was an actress, known for Tokyo Story (1953), Maborosi (1995) and Floating Weeds (1959). She died on January 23, 2005 in Yoyogi, Tokyo.
biography.name: Mutsuko Sakura

biography.bio: Toyo Takahashi was born on July 15, 1903 in Tokyo, Japan as Toyoko Takahashi. She was an actress, known for Tokyo Story (1953), Late Spring (1949) and Début d'été (1951). She died on March 14, 1981.
biography.name: Toyo Takahashi

biography.bio: Tôru Abe was born on March 28, 1917 in Fukuoka, Japan. He was an actor, known for Tokyo Story (1953), The Human Condition I: No Greater Love (1959) and Shogun (1980). He died on July 18, 1993.
biography.name: Tôru Abe

titlesAwards.titleAwardOutcome: Won OFTA Film Hall of Fame
